data.title: Catscratch
data.meta_description: Catscratch is an American animated television series and the twenty-first major Nicktoon created by Doug TenNapel for Nickelodeon. It is a light-hearted adaptation of TenNapel's graphic novel, Gear. The series features music, which was composed by longtime TenNapel collaborator, Terry Scott...
data.text:
Catscratch is an American animated television series and the twenty-first major Nicktoon created by Doug TenNapel for Nickelodeon. It is a light-hearted adaptation of TenNapel's graphic novel, Gear. The series features music, which was composed by longtime TenNapel collaborator, Terry Scott Taylor. The show is twenty episodes long, tying with The X's and Rock, Paper, Scissors. It is has six episodes less than El Tigre: The Adventures of Manny Rivera, Tak and the Power of Juju, Bunsen is a Beast, Planet Sheen, and Robot and Monster, and has ten episodes less than Welcome to the Wayne. It, along with The X’s, had the least episode premieres.

Show Summary[]

Gordon Quid, Waffle, and Mr. Blik were raised in a mansion by Mrs. Edna Cramdilly, who left them her house and her fortune when she died. The brothers live a life of freedom, adventure, and total madness. They are served by a butler named Hovis, who often supports them on their countless adventures. They will even stop the Chumpy Chump Brothers from annoying and causing them trouble once and for all!

Characters[]

Main article: List of Catscratch characters

Gordon Quid[]

Gordon is an orange & white cat who is highly generous. He has a Scottish accent and claims to be part of the Highland Quint Clan, despite Blik telling Gordon he was born under the couch like him and Waffle, though later on he is made into an honorary member of the clan. He is highly addictive to food and makes traditional Scottish meals that other people completely despise or does not have the chance to eat it before he does. He is also best friends with Kimberly whom he loves though she sees him as merely a friend due to her young age. He has a low singing voice, which annoys his elder brother, Blik.

Waffle[]

Waffle is a mau and an innocent bonehead. He is one of the only characters of the show that care for others apart from him. He has a newt he named Gomez. Waffles personality is perky, but dumb and is always happy-go-lucky. However, there are some moments where Waffle demonstrates incredible intelligence, such as giving the definition, explanation of a particular word and/or even its circumstance.

Mr. Blik[]

Mr. Blik is a greedy black cat and a total jerk, but still cares for his brothers in his own way. He has a little bit of heart for Waffle, as seen in To The Moon. He cries for Waffle as they fly back to earth and leave him behind. He is the only one who is highly intelligent, but is greedy.

Trivia[]

Many of the cast members in Catscratch were cast in Disney's Lilo & Stitch: The Series, which was airing around the same time.

Liliana Mumy, who voiced Human Kimberly also portrayed Mertle Edmonds.

Rob Paulsen, who voiced Gordon, portrayed Experiment 625 (Reuben).

Kevin McDonald, who voiced Waffle, portrayed Pleakley.

Frank Welker, who voiced Randall the Bear, portrayed multiple experiments.

Episodes[]

Main article: Catscratch episode list

Broadcast history[]

Nickelodeon (original run, July 9, 2005-February 10, 2007; reruns, February 11-June 3, 2007; November 22, 2007)

NickToons (November 25, 2007-January 1, 2009; December 19, 2015)

Comics[]

Confirmed by an e-mail from Doug TenNapel, there were some 2-page Catscratch comics in the works for Nickelodeon Magazine. The first one appeared in the December/January 2006 issue. It is unknown when the other comics first appeared.

In other media[]

Waffle appears in the plug and play TV game, Nicktoons: Summer Camp.

Mr. Blik appears as a playable character in the Nintendo DS version of Nicktoons: Attack of the ToyBots, while he appeared as a master model in the BlueTongue (Wii and Playstation 2) version.

Home media[]

The series was featured on the Nick Picks series on DVD. Volume 3 contained the episode "Bringing Down the Mouse", while "Love Cats" was featured on the fifth volume. The episode "Lovesick" was planned to be featured on the cancelled sixth volume.
